11:10 am
BE

The announcement of Tsinghua Unigroup as 3% holders will likely reignite M&A speculation around Imagination once again. We update our numbers to account for new management cost cutting and Apple’s quarterly numbers last week. The latter were not pretty for iPhone units for the June quarter, and there are a few tricky quarters in store here, but Mediatek share regain, Spreadtrum progress and management action on cost should offset. We remain Buyers with an upgraded 200p price target.
Tsinghua Unigroup’s acquisition of a 3% stake is interesting considering this is the Chinese state-backed technology holding company that acquired RDA Microelectronics and Spreadtrum (with Intel also having a 20% stake). The idea that the Chinese state’s acquisition of IP is a strategic priority, and that IMG could be a target, has been floated before, but considered slightly left-field. As a result, the announcement brings this idea to the forefront, with Tsinghua having stated in press reports that it expects to invest c.$47bn in the next five years, and reignites M&A speculation over IMG more generally.
We have updated numbers for the recent trading updates and Apple’s Q2 results last week. With c.38m iPhone units implied for the June quarter, down c.10m on US sell-side expectations, this is not a great start for IMG’s FY17E in royalty unit terms. We assume a 10% drop (c.23m units) in Apple units for IMG’s FY17E; the release of the iPhone 7 in September is all important. Against this, FY17E should be the year where IMG starts recovering share in Mediatek and gains ground within Spreadtrum (previously a 100% Mali stronghold), leading to our overall GPU royalty units being broadly flat in FY17E, albeit at a reduced royalty rate. With a more pragmatic management team in charge, and only c.10% EBIT margins on new FY17E forecasts, there should still be scope for further cost cuts if necessary to offset further royalty weakness.
We reset our target price to 200p based on a 10% discount to the average 12-month forward EV/Sales multiple since 2008 (5x). Apple’s next two quarters look tricky, constraining short term upgrade momentum for Imagination, but the new management approach acts as a cushion, with M&A optionality, and so we remain at Buy.

BE

Yes, but why does it reignite takeover speculation?

BE

We know Apple talked to Imagination, because they were kind enough to tell us on the back of that Ars Technica story.

11:11 am
BE

BE

BE

11:16 am
BE

Have some Credit Suisse as well.

BE

Tsinghua Unigroup has 3% stake in Imagination Tech. IMG disclosed today
that Chinese state-backed technology firm Tsinghua Unigroup now has a 3%
stake in the company. Note as per a Reuters story (in Nov 2015), Tsinghua has
plans to invest $47bn over the next 5 years in a bid to become the world's 3rd
largest chipmaker (currently Intel, Samsung and Qualcomm are the three leading
chip companies).
■ Reignites debate around potential M&A. Given Tsinghua's involvement in a
number of acquisitions in the tech space in the last few years, this 3% stake in
IMG will re-ignite the debate around potential acquisition of IMG. Tsinghua had
acquired Spreadtrum and RDA in late 2013 (two Taiwanese chip companies for
$1.8bn and $0.9bn respectively), 51% stake in HP's H3C Technologies in May-15
(for $2.3bn), 6% stake in Lattice Semiconductor in Apr-16 (~$600mn market cap
company, through share purchases in the open market). However, its attempts to
buy Micron in Jul-15 (for $23bn) and also 15% stake in Western Digital in Sep-15
(for $3.8mn) failed due to security concerns from the US government. This
disclosure of 3% stake held by Tsinghua in IMG follows news story in Mar-16
when Apple (which already owns 8% stake in IMG) noted that it had some
discussions with IMG, but does not plan to make an offer at this time.

BE

■ High Apple exposure makes things somewhat complicated. With IMG being
the sole IP supplier for graphics in iPhones/iPads, Apple accounted for £60mn of
IMG sales in FY15 (~35% of group), which we expect to rise to 40-45% in FY16
(as Intel's 12% contribution declines significantly). With such high revenue
exposure and also Apple having 8% stake in IMG, it makes any potential deal
complicated for Tsinghua especially if Apple were to discontinue the use of IMG's
graphics post any deal with the Chinese entity. However, we also believe that
Tsinghua can see IMG as an opportunity to have in-house graphics as it tries to
revive the two acquired chip businesses (Spreadtrum and RDA) over time.
■ M&A speculation to sideline underlying fundamentals for now. With IMG
expected to deliver EPS of 5.90p/5.25p (with PURE) in FY17/FY18, and
6.25p/5.45p (without PURE losses), shares trading at more than 30x on FY18 remain
expensive. But with ongoing debate around potential M&A, we believe this may
continue to mask IMG's structural issues in its underlying GPU/CPU businesses.

Avanti Communications Group PLC (AVN:LSE): Last: 99.88, up 9.13 (+10.06%), High: 107.00, Low: 97.00, Volume: 2.16m

Avanti Communications Group plc ("Avanti" or "the Group"), a leading provider of satellite data communications services in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, announces that it has won a contract to supply EE Limited with satellite capacity for cellular backhaul.

Avanti will connect a number of cellular sites across the UK to EE's network using the HYLAS 1 and 2 satellites, to provide communications in remote areas and additional network resilience.

The first phase of this multiyear contract has an initial value of $29m, plus options to double the capacity.

PM

An important contract win announcement out this morning, not only in financial terms but also as a lead indicator for future commercial momentum. Avanti has won a contract to provide EE in the UK with cellular backhaul services - without being explicit in the release, we'd presume this is to support EE in December 2015 win to provide UK emergency services users a dedicated 4G network. The first phase of the multiyear contract has an initial value of $29m (34% of FY15 revenue) with an option to double capacity. Speaking to the company this morning we understand that: 1. The number of sites is well into the high single digit 100s, with a mix of primary and redundant sites; 2. This was a competitive tender with Avanti able to face off competition with its cheaper "per bit" pricing inherent in its high throughput capacity; 3. Indeed, the contract has also "met" the long running $2,000 MHz / month price point; and 4. The contract starts immediately. In our view this is a positive development – not only is it a material source of revenue growth with upside potential – but perhaps more importantly, cellular backhaul has long been touted as a critical application for high throughput capacity driven growth (not just for Avanti, but for the whole industry) – to see Avanti secure a material deployment with a “household” name in a major market certainly ticks a number of boxes. As the shares have drifted to below 100p on perennial liquidity concerns, Avanti’s price book ratio has dropped to only 0.6x (peers on 2-3x). We’d expect a positive price response today.

BE

Greggs AGM statement revealed that it continues to enjoy a good start to the year. L4L
sales moderated slightly since the prelims due to a softer March, but trading has since
recovered towards the level of the first eight weeks and remain ahead of our forecast
assumptions. The shop refurbishment and upgrade programme remains on track and
the consultation on the supply chain investments has been successfully concluded.
Looking forward, there is plenty to do. Greggs is only in the second year of a five-year
plan to transform itself from a high street retailer to a bakery food-on-the-go operator. We
retain our forecasts, BUY recommendation and 1325p share price target.

11:32 am
BE

Detail
L4L sales were 3.7% for the first 18 weeks, down from +4.2% at the prelims (8 weeks),
implying L4L sales of +3.3% for the 10 week period. We assume +3.0% L4L sales as
a basis for our estimates. The dip was due to a softer Easter and weather affected
March and trading subsequently recovered through April. L4L sales were driven by hot
sandwiches and breakfast helped by the introduction of flat white coffee. The spring
salad range has now been launched in the shops nationwide just in time for the fine
weather (!). Extremes of weather are not helpful but Greggs doesn't mind too much
whether it is hot (salads and soft drinks) or cold (savouries and coffee).
Greggs has completed 55 of the final 200 old-style shop refurbs scheduled for this year
which also drive positive L4L sales. It has also opened 43 new shops and closed 21
shops including 23 franchised units in motorway or garage locations. Access to airports
and railway terminals is proving tougher to open up. It continues to build a foothold in
Ireland with the first company-owned store now opened in Belfast. The consultation
on the £100m supply chain investment proposals has been successful concluded
with the principles being accepted by the unions. The programme is to transform the
twelve regional bakeries into nine national production centres of excellence with a
logistics capability to service the accelerating new store roll-out. The first site at Sleaford,
Lincolnshire has already closed with Twickenham scheduled for 4Q16 and Edinburgh for
2Q17.

BE

At Friday's close Greggs' share price traded on a FY16E P/E of 18.2x, EV/EBITDA of 8.7x
and FCF yield of 5.0% falling to 16.6x, 8.0x and 5.7% for FY17E. Our 1325p share price
target is based on a basket of valuation metrics including dividend yield and DCF. Adding
'specials' to our dividend calculations generates an underlying 4.0%-5.0% yield over
our explicit forecast time scale, which is attractive in a yield-hungry world. Our DCF also
points to a high intrinsic value, a view underpinned by Quest®

11:33 am
BE

BE

11:34 am
BE

Here's Shore. Or a bit of Shore anyway.

BE

Modernising the offer
The self-improvement programme that has been engineered by Greggs, most particularly through the leadership of CEO Roger Whiteside, has been impressive to our minds. Pretty much root & branch change has been made to the overall proposition, its merchandising and the ease and accessibility of its consumption. Accordingly, Greggs has understood what it is appreciated for by some many customers - sausage rolls to steak bakes - whilst transforming its drinks, breakfast offer, sandwiches & rolls, sweet lines and most recently a strong boxed salad offering. It is fair to say, in our view, that Greggs is particularly advancing in hot food.

Greggs’ management on the call with analyst spoke of mixed customer count and average transaction values through the 18-week period under review. However, at an underlying level the development of the proposition seems to be advancing mix; for example higher ticket salad lines. Considerable progress has been made at breakfast time and much current NPD work is focusing upon lunchtime; later in the day remains an opportunity for growth but one that is further down the line.

Value has remained to the core of the Greggs' offer but we also believe that some of the most important adjustments to the change programme have emerged from the ongoing estate management. Stores across the estate have been refreshed, relocated and modernised; Greggs refurbished 55 stores in the 18-week period under review. Seating has emerged as an important builder of basket size to our minds, with many folk adding drinks to savouries for example, and from recent store visits we see Greggs becoming increasing capable and confident with sit down locations.

PM

BE

11:36 am
BE

We have admired Greggs as a company for many years; its values, it evolution and its prospects. Recent trade, against weak high street footfall and a tough comparison of 6.0%, is impressive as Greggs sustains its heritage in a more modern and sustainable context. There is much more for this group to go at to deliver onward earnings and dividend growth. As such, balancing off reasonably fair and fulsome valuation metrics compared to other F2G, mid-cap food producers and retailers, we deem Greggs' shares as a solid HOLD.

PM

We’ve focused on creating technology that reflects how people actually live and work from day to day - and that enables a new, better, deeper understanding of consumers as people and citizens. Five years ago our vision was to bring consumers’ stories to life on video. We started with video because it is the most engaging medium, and because we thought it would become a medium of choice for storytelling.

We took out a real sofa into the street and created our own authentic, conversational video content. We don't do that so much now - we tend to deal in mobile uploads or content created by other partners - but the philosophy behind what we were doing hasn't changed. We want to be able to use video and still images - as functional and productive media to help organisations and individuals build greater human understanding, create better ideas, and transform their futures.

BE

G4S’s Q116 trading statement reads reassuringly and we focus on the positive
tone, the implied margin improvement and better cashflow.
 Ashley Almanza, CEO, said “Against a backdrop of macro-economic
uncertainty, the Group had a positive start to the year. We continued to
implement our strategy to transform the Group’s focus and performance and
this is reflected in our revenue growth and improving profit and cash
generation.”
 Constant currency revenue growth in Q1 was 4.5%, which compares to
4.0% in FY15. We think we can assume most of this was organic growth as
G4S has not announced material acquisitions (in 2015, G4S had organic
revenue growth of 2.2% in H11 and 3.6% in H215).

BE

No margin is given but PBITA growth was 6.5%, implying a further
margin increase. The margin rose 10bp in FY15 to 6.6%.
 There were no new onerous contract charges or impairments.
 Operating cash flow for the three months was an inflow of £86 million
compared with £5 million in 2015, of which £24 million related to the
reversal in working capital from the fourth quarter 2015.

BE

 Estimates: We have maintained our estimates. We forecast EPS of 15.9p in
FY16 (3.5% ahead of Bloomberg consensus 15.4p) and 17.3p in FY17
(3.7% ahead of Bloomberg consensus 16.7p). Our estimates assume 4.2%
and then 4.7% organic revenue growth, and after a margin of 6.6% in FY15
a margin of 6.8% and then 6.9%.
 Recommendation: We have an Overweight recommendation on G4S. On
the negative side, G4S’s ND/EBITDA rose to 3.3x in FY15. On the positive
side, underlying trading is good and we think leverage will decline. G4S
trades on a 2017E PER of 10.6x, compared to Prosegur (Neutral) on 15.5x
and Securitas (Underweight) on 14.8x.

We leave our forecasts (which include £6,454m sales and £433m PBITA for FY16) unchanged following this update. We retain our Neutral rating and 190p Target Price

material changes to consensus forecasts today. The stock has clearly been weak (-18% YTD underperformance vs FTSE100) and headline valuations appear
undemanding (16E PE 13x, Div Yield 5.1%) and so there may be some relief today. However, we continue to believe the group has challenges in its higher
margin areas and that the balance sheet/pension remains an issue. We remain at Underperform.

BE

Short term uncertainty overrides long-term opportunity
Restaurant Group's profit warning on 29th April highlighted a deteriorating LFL trend,
with -2.7% LFL for the 17 weeks to 24 April indicating a LFL decline of -4.4% for the
last 7 weeks. Management appear yet to have a clear explanation for the weakness, let
alone a solution. As a result, we are cautious on the near term potential for a LFL
turnaround. Whilst there is some valuation support at these levels, we downgrade from
Buy to Neutral to reflect the lack of visibility, pending details of the strategic review.

BE

LFL weakness a combination of factors, but clarity on problem is limited
The sharp decline in group LFL growth looks to be a combination of; (1) tougher
consumer backdrop; (2) increased competition driven by strong supply growth; (3)
brand positioning. In particular, there are clearly questions around the brand
positioning of F&B, and how effectively it can compete against newer formats. The LFL
run-rate implies F&B could be seeing near double-digit LFL declines if you assume other
brands are flat, and Pubs & concessions are growing by +2%.

BE

Reduce forecast for LFL growth and new site openings
The group have launched a strategic review of the business, however, we don't expect
any detail until August, and see limited scope for solutions that will meaningfully
change the underlying trends in 2016. As a result, we now forecast LFL growth for
2016 of -4.0% vs. management guidance of -2% to -5%, and 2016 PBT of £74.9m
vs. guidance of £74-80m. In addition, we forecast new openings of 30 this year to
reflect more caution in choice of new sites as part of the strategic review. However, we
note that the group remains cash generative despite our forecast margin decline, which
implies a 2016E FCF yield of 6.4%, and a c.13% yield excluding expansionary capex.

11:57 am
BE

Valuation: Price target of 305p based on relative multiple valuation
We change our valuation methodology from DCF to relative multiples to reflect the
uncertainty surrounding the strategy of the group, pending the ongoing review. We
value RTN on 10.5x 2016E P/E, in line with the pubs sector (range 6.9x – 14.3x, average
10.5x). Our DCF valuation remains higher at 430p reflecting the potential long-term
opportunity, but does not incorporate the heightened execution risk given the ongoing
strategic review.

BE
